body.creator: Olivia Flores
body.value: The blinding white light emits another blue lens flare. These visual elements are often markers of Lena and Barry’s love, or, in the case of white, of the oppressive stress that Barry feels. Of special importance in this moment, though, is the unexplained otherworldly noise, somewhere between a buzz and a ringing, that can be heard as the camera settles on this lamp. Without Lena present, it serves as a warning from afar: Barry’s decision to call the phone sex line will lead to trouble.

body.creator: Olivia Flores
body.value: Cinematographer Robert Elswit explains the logic behind the camera's erratic movement in this scene: "At one point Sandler's character is being followed by the Steadicam as he talks on the phone. During a take, the front of the camera bumped into a table and knocked the camera briefly, causing the shot to jump from Sandler to an image of an out-of-focus piece of the set and then quickly re-adjust. 'Most directors would probably not even print that take,' says Elswit, 'but Paul loved the effect and wanted to do it again. So we did more takes and right at the same point in the dialog, I'd sort of smack the front of the matte box to re-create the look.' Though a final cut wasn't completed by press time, Elswit believes the shot, for which no other coverage exists, will remain in the final film" ("Interview: Behind The Scenes With Robert Elswit").
